awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Developing Business Communication Skills in Manufacturing Technician Education
awd_abstract_narration:
The advanced manufacturing and production fields have growing need for skilled technicians who can communicate effectively in teams.  In response to this workforce demand, the project team will develop and test an adaptive virtual reality (VR) platform to help manufacturing technician students learn business communication skills.  The platform will deliver interactive case studies that allow students to practice business communication skills needed in a smart factory context.  To support integration of these adaptive VR case studies within courses, faculty in advanced manufacturing programs will participate in extensive professional development as they collaboratively develop new VR business communication case studies.  In addition, the project will support faculty externships in industry to enhance their knowledge of current trends, skills requirements, new tools, and career opportunities in advanced manufacturing.  This knowledge will help them improve their teaching and better serve their students.  To strengthen the alignment between coursework and job tasks, the project draws on the long-standing partnership between Ivy Tech Community College of Indiana, Purdue University, and industry partners.  Recognizing that the incumbent manufacturing workforce is maturing, the project also focuses on fostering and investigating the communication skills that facilitate the transfer of highly specialized technical skills, knowledge, and expertise across the multiple generations in the manufacturing workforce. 

The intellectual merit of the project rests on the implementation of a research and development cycle that facilitates the development, testing, investigation, and revision of project activities and deliverables for improvement and goal attainment (e.g., advanced manufacturing technicians who develop the technical knowledge and skills, as well as the soft skills to work efficiently and effectively in modern manufacturing).  To answer a priori and emerging questions, the project will conduct a mixed methods study to advance knowledge of the effectiveness of integrating the learning of technical knowledge/skills with soft skills in curricular and educational materials (i.e., case studies within a virtual reality platform).  The quantitative and qualitative study will examine the integration of manufacturing and communication job tasks through pre-post outcomes assessments, structured interviews and focus groups, descriptive and trend analyses, analyses of the quality of deliverables and products, and thematic content analyses of information from interviews, focus group discussions, and open-ended survey questions. This project is funded by the Advanced Technological Education program that focuses on the education of technicians for the advanced-technology fields that drive the nation's economy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
“Developing Business Communication Skills in Manufacturing Technical Education” was a collaborative research project partnering Ivy Technical Community College with Purdue University to innovate technical education in Indiana, specifically to incorporate more soft skills development into the curriculum for manufacturing technicians, to leverage emerging technologies in the classroom, and to connect faculty with local manufacturing contexts. The study had three goals, including 1) Develop and test the effectiveness of an adaptive virtual reality (VR)-based business communication skills education program for manufacturing technician students; 2) Conduct and facilitate a one-day interdisciplinary faculty development workshop for enhancing curriculum and educational materials through writing new case studies of business communication skills in a manufacturing context and compiling the case studies into a manuscript; 3) Create an externship program for faculty in manufacturing technician education; and 4) Evaluate the project and disseminate findings.

 

Despite delays in virtual reality content development caused by COVID and student participant recruitment challenges, the project team completed all study objectives during a no cost extension of the original three-year grant. An external evaluator concluded that the PI and Co-PIs were successful in assessing the learning effectiveness of the virtual reality simulations created for this project and implemented with Ivy Tech Manufacturing Education students. Based on both quantitative (pre-posttest survey data comparison) and qualitative (thematic analysis of student reflective writing), the team presented evidence in scholarly presentations and publications that the VR simulations engaged students in experiential learning effectively and led to increased intercultural competence learning gains as compared to a control group of Ivy Tech students who studied Business Communication without completing the VR intervention.

 

In addition, the evaluation demonstrated that the case studies developed by Ivy Tech faculty and published in a monograph for use with manufacturing technology students enhanced participants’ related knowledge and skill level. Faculty externships in local manufacturing plants provided valuable applied learning opportunities for participants, informing faculty understanding of the developmental needs of current students to be hire-ready for these local work settings and strengthening community-institution relationships to benefit future joint projects. The external evaluator also determined that this project’s educational model can be adapted more widely within Ivy Tech’s statewide system and across multiple disciplines.

 

Open access outputs generated by the project comprise:

1)       The virtual reality simulations, publicly available for free download from Purdue University’s Research Repository at https://purr.purdue.edu/publications/4082/1 for use with Oculus VR headset systems. Note: With additional funding from the Lily Foundation, a web-based 360 video version of the simulations has since been paired with an AI (ChatGPT) mentored debriefing, accessible at https://ai-innovation-project.web.app/.

2)      The case study monograph, published in Purdue University’s e-pubs at https://docs.lib.purdue.edu/atecases/.

3)      Two manuscripts (one on quantitative data and the other qualitative) in preparation and under review at scholarly journals at the time of this report.

 

In addition to the benefits accrued by the Ivy Technical Community College faculty and students, the project financially supported and offered research skill professional development to a graduate student and two undergraduate students at Purdue University and employed several student workers at statewide Ivy Tech locations during the project implementation.
